awd_titl_txt: Microscale Mechanics of Temporomandibular Joint Articular Cartilage
awd_abstract_narration:
The mechanical requirements for the cartilage that lines the jaw - known as the temporomandibular joint or TMJ - are particularly demanding. During chewing and grinding, this tissue experiences repetitive loading with high levels of compression and sliding.  As a result, this cartilage fails quite frequently, as is evidenced by the fact that 4-7 percent of the population of the United States experiences TMJ disorders. Notably, the structure of the cartilage in this joint is quite different from other joints, and how the structure of this tissue relates to its mechanical function is not well understood. The long term goal of this project is to understand the how mechanical properties of the articular cartilage of the TMJ relate to the microstructure and composition of the tissue in both health and disease. Such knowledge will increase understanding of how the cartilage of the TMJ fails in individuals with TMJ disorders.  The techniques developed in this research will be incorporated into laboratory courses taken by engineering and biology students, which will enable them to apply this approach to a wide variety of tissues and organisms. Additionally, the PIs will develop and implement courses and seminars on scientific communication for graduate students, with direct outreach to students from under-represented populations.  

This project will use a state-of-the-art technique that enables measurement of the mechanical properties of cartilage to a high level of spatial resolution while relating of these properties to the local composition of the tissue.  Imaging techniques include confocal elastography, paloarimetry, and FTIR microscopy.  Using this combination of mechanical testing and imaging methods, this project will characterize the spatial, functional, and structural basis of the mechanical properties of the TMJ. This will be include linear and non-linear properties for both compression and shear loading based on surface location, depth, and direction of shear force during normal loading scenarios.  The mechanical properties will be correlated via location with local concentrations of collagen and aggrecan. Successful completion of this project will provide foundational understanding of the microstructural basis for the mechanics of cartilage from the TMJ.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The temporomandibular joint (TMJ) is unique in that it is the only joint that does not support movement of the whole body or extremities. The motion of TMJ due to chewing and grinding of food results in a structure of the mandibular cartilage that is distinct from other joints. It is well established that this cartilage has a highly aligned and fibrous surface zone that is absent in other types of articular cartilage. Our work sheds important new light on the functional implications of the structure of this tissue. Using a combination of advanced microscopy techniques, we mapped the structure and mechanical properties of TMJ condyle cartilage to a resolution of 50 microns. We showed that this fibrous surface zone is 1000 times softer than the cartilage near the bone and that this transition in stiffness occurs over a small length scale, ~200 microns.  We further showed that this stiffness is highly sensitive to the density of the extracellular matrix, with 2-fold changes in density causing 20-fold increases in stiffness. Lastly, we demonstrated important differences in these structure-property relationships between human TMJ cartilage and that from pigs, which are the most common animal model used to study TMJ disease.

 Collectively, our work highlights the importance of evaluating the mechanics of connective tissues on the microscale, which revealed the role of the zonal structure of TMJ cartilage.  Further, we identified the need to develop and modify existing animal models of disease to more accurately represent the behavior of human tissue.

 

Broader Impacts

Approximately 10 million people in the US, or 1 in 25 adults, experience TMJ disease, which is painful and highly debilitating. An important consequence of this disease is damage and loss to the cartilage that lines the joint, but the mechanism of this process is not well understood. In particular, the microscale processes that lead to tissue damage are understudied. Our work suggests that loss of the top 100-200 microns of the tissue is a hallmark of the disease and that the tissue in this region provides a unique mechanical role. Further, our work demonstrates important differences between the microscale mechanics of human cartilage and that from animals such as pigs that are often used as models for human disease. Such data suggest that modifications of tissue from these animals may be needed to more accurately model human tissue.

 A powerful tool used in our studies is the microscopy-based mechanical testing and digital image correlation used to measure tissue stiffness on the scale of 20-50 microns. Because this technique is an emerging tool in the community, we have developed three modules in the course BME 4490, Biomechanics Laboratory, that use this technique. Over the course of this grant, approximately 50 undergraduate students have been trained on this cutting edge technique.
